key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning method learns rich representations of time-varying neuronal activity that enable high-content, scalable phenotypic screening to identify genetic modifiers of neuronal dynamics. This approach captures single-cell temporal patterns in the context of network interactions without requiring large labeled datasets.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap between complex, time-resolved neuronal activity data and scalable discovery of genetic perturbations by eliminating heavy label-dependence and explicitly accounting for network context, enabling sensitive detection of phenotypic effects on dynamic activity patterns.
method: Design self-supervised pretext tasks that exploit temporal structure of calcium/electrophysiology traces and relationships among neurons to learn embeddings without labels.
Incorporate network-aware priors (neuron-to-neuron connectivity or co-activity) so learned representations reflect both single-cell dynamics and local circuit context.
Use the learned embeddings for downstream high-throughput screening to cluster phenotypes and detect genetic modifiers (compare perturbation vs control, prioritize hits).
impact: Provides a practical blueprint for applying self-supervised and graph-aware representation learning to biological time series, reducing annotation needs and increasing throughput and sensitivity for discovery tasks—relevant to ML practitioners working on biomedical signals, spatio-temporal data, and causal screening.
visual_elements: Pipeline schematic: data (activity traces + network) → network-aware self-supervised model → embeddings → hit detection
UMAP/t-SNE of learned embeddings colored by genotype/perturbation to show phenotype separation
Heatmap or raster plots of representative neuronal activity traces before/after a genetic perturbation
Bar/ROC chart comparing hit discovery sensitivity and false positive rate vs baseline (supervised or non-network methods)
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
